name: pupy

procedures: T1003.001::[Pupy] can execute Lazagne as well as [Mimikatz] using PowerShell.
T1003.004::[Pupy] can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
T1003.005::[Pupy] can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
T1016::[Pupy] has built in commands to identify a host’s IP address and find out other network configuration settings by viewing connected sessions.
T1021.001::[Pupy] can enable/disable RDP connection and can start a remote desktop session using a browser web socket client.
T1033::[Pupy] can enumerate local information for Linux hosts and find currently logged on users for Windows hosts.
T1041::[Pupy] can send screenshots files, keylogger data, files, and recorded audio back to the C2 server.
T1046::[Pupy] has a built-in module for port scanning.
T1049::[Pupy] has a built-in utility command for netstat, can do net session through PowerView, and has an interactive shell which can be used to discover additional information.
T1055.001::[Pupy] can migrate into another process using reflective DLL injection.
T1056.001::[Pupy] uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes it then sends back to the server after it is stopped.
T1057::[Pupy] can list the running processes and get the process ID and parent process’s ID.
T1059.001::[Pupy] has a module for loading and executing PowerShell scripts.

T1059.006::[Pupy] can use an add on feature when creating payloads that allows you to create custom Python scripts (“scriptlets”) to perform tasks offline (without requiring a session) such as sandbox detection, adding persistence, etc.
T1070.001::[Pupy] has a module to clear event logs with PowerShell.
T1071.001::[Pupy] can communicate over HTTP for C2.
T1082::[Pupy] can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.
T1083::[Pupy] can walk through directories and recursively search for strings in files.
T1087.001::[Pupy] uses PowerView and Pywerview to perform discovery commands such as net user, net group, net local group, etc.
T1105::[Pupy] can upload and download to/from a victim machine.
T1113::[Pupy] can drop a mouse-logger that will take small screenshots around at each click and then send back to the server.
T1114.001::[Pupy] can interact with a victim’s Outlook session and look through folders and emails.
T1123::[Pupy] can record sound with the microphone.
T1125::[Pupy] can access a connected webcam and capture pictures.
T1134.001::[Pupy] can obtain a list of SIDs and provide the option for selecting process tokens to impersonate.
T1135::[Pupy] can list local and remote shared drives and folders over SMB.
T1136.001::[Pupy] can user PowerView to execute “net user” commands and create local system accounts.
T1136.002::[Pupy] can user PowerView to execute “net user” commands and create domain accounts.
T1497.001::[Pupy] has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.
T1543.002::[Pupy] can be used to establish persistence using a systemd service.
T1547.001::[Pupy] adds itself to the startup folder or adds itself to the Registry key SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run for persistence.
T1548.002::[Pupy] can bypass Windows UAC through either DLL hijacking, eventvwr, or appPaths.
T1550.003::[Pupy] can also perform pass-the-ticket.
T1552.001::[Pupy] can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
T1555.003::[Pupy] can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
T1555::[Pupy] can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
T1557.001::[Pupy] can sniff plaintext network credentials and use NBNS Spoofing to poison name services.
T1560.001::[Pupy] can compress data with Zip before sending it over C2.
T1569.002::[Pupy] uses [PsExec] to execute a payload or commands on a remote host.
T1573.002::[Pupy]'s default encryption for its C2 communication channel is SSL, but it also has transport options for RSA and AES.

description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
